citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, at approx. 12 PM on Aug. 5, 2025, the adult male umbrella cockatoo, Nigel, bit the finger of a
child that stuck his finger into the enclosure where Nigel was kept. The bite broke the skin on the child's finger, causing it
to bleed and need bandaged. The incident was documented on facility records and there was no injury to the animal. The
facility representative conveyed that "Nigel" has only been on exhibit in that enclosure for approx. 2-3 weeks and there
are signs saying not to touch, and that the birds bite. The enclosure is located near to the ticket windows but there is no
attendant present nor public barriers preventing access by the public to the enclosure.
Lack of sufficient distance and/or barriers can lead to stress and injury to the animals, as well as injury to the general
viewing public.
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals
and the public.
Correct by: Aug. 12, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1)  Repeat
   
Handling of animals. 
At the time of inspection, at approx. 12 PM on Aug. 5, 2025, the adult male umbrella cockatoo, Nigel, bit the finger of a 
child that stuck his finger into the enclosure where Nigel was kept. The bite broke the skin on the child's finger, causing it 
to bleed and need bandaged. The incident was documented on facility records and there was no injury to the animal. The 
facility representative conveyed that "Nigel" has only been on exhibit in that enclosure for approx. 2-3 weeks and there 
are signs saying not to touch, and that the birds bite. The enclosure is located near to the ticket windows but there is no 
attendant present nor public barriers preventing access by the public to the enclosure.  
 
Lack of sufficient distance and/or barriers can lead to stress and injury to the animals, as well as injury to the general 
viewing public.  
 
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with 
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals 
and the public.  
 
Correct by: Aug. 12, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
